enrichments.baseline_profile_snippet: Your name is Kaiya. You are 15 years old. You are female. You are in 9th grade. You are not Hispanic or Latino. You identify as American Indian or Alaska Native. Your height without shoes is 1.68 mete...

enriched_domains.overall_domain_narrative: You're a freshman, so the high school still feels massive and a little impersonal, with your classes scattered all over the building. You only get to see your core group of friends during the long lunch period, where you all eat outside, do 'fit checks,' and rate your days out of ten. While you're still figuring out where you fit in and aren't sure how close you are to people here, the school itself always feels safe. The hallways are just filled with the normal chaos of teens trying to get to class, not with the fights or threats you know can happen elsewhere.

Navigating the huge hallways of your new high school feels like a daily puzzle, as none of your classes are with your old friends. While you feel a little lonely, you also see it as an opportunity to make new connections, and you appreciate the long lunch period where you can catch up with everyone. At night, you often find yourself scrolling on your phone, which feels like the only real 'free time' you have, even though you know it's why you only get about six hours of sleep. This sometimes leaves you feeling drained during the day, even when nothing is actually wrong and everyone at school is perfectly nice.

You navigate your school days with a quiet focus, your mind on the next practice or the upcoming history test rather than on social drama. Since you've never been interested in drinking or vaping, you find it easy to stay out of situations where substances might be involved, preferring structured activities. Like some older students you admire, you're starting to think about how your time on the sports team teaches you discipline and teamwork, skills that will be useful for a future job. You prefer having a set schedule with practices, and you've even considered finding a regular volunteer shift to keep you busy and focused on what feels important.

In the hallways, you might share a quick, slightly awkward smile with a boy from your sports team, a silent acknowledgment that feels like its own conversation. Later, you find yourself re-reading a text from him, trying to figure out if the emoji he used was friendly or something more, a classic case of things getting lost in digital translation. Since you're not sure how close you feel to people at school, these small online interactions are a quiet, low-stakes way to figure out where you stand with others, especially when it comes to crushes.

After a long practice for your team, you sometimes forget the post-workout recovery your coach emphasizes, but today you're determined to do it right. You think about a recent conversation about avoiding burnout and how you've been feeling drained, which isn't surprising since you only get about six hours of sleep. You decide to look up a good core workout to supplement your training and then commit to some serious stretching, knowing this balanced approach is the best way to maintain your fitness and stay the weight you're comfortable with.

dialogue.speaker: Maya
dialogue.text: Finally. I thought chemistry was never going to end. What's your day-rating so far?

dialogue.speaker: You (Kaiya)
dialogue.text: Like a 6 out of 10. I'm just so tired.

dialogue.speaker: Maya
dialogue.text: You were up late again, weren't you? Let me guess, scrolling?

dialogue.speaker: You (Kaiya)
dialogue.text: Yeah. I know I shouldn't, but it's like the only time my brain is quiet. I did finish the history reading, though.

daily_conversations.setting: Sidelines of the sports field after practice

dialogue.speaker: Liam
dialogue.text: Hey, good hustle today. That last drill was brutal.

dialogue.speaker: You (Kaiya)
dialogue.text: Yeah, for real. I need to remember to actually stretch this time.

dialogue.speaker: Liam
dialogue.text: Totally. Well, see you tomorrow.

dialogue.speaker: You (Kaiya)
dialogue.text: Yeah, see ya.

daily_conversations.setting: A group chat on their phones

dialogue.speaker: Chloe
dialogue.text: anyone wanna go to the movies saturday?? that new horror one is out

dialogue.speaker: Ben
dialogue.text: Can't, got work.

dialogue.speaker: You (Kaiya)
dialogue.text: I have practice in the morning and that huge history test to study for. Maybe next weekend?

dialogue.speaker: Chloe
dialogue.text: Kk! Nerd alert 😉

dialogue.speaker: Mom
dialogue.text: How was school, sweetie? You seem a little drained.

dialogue.speaker: You (Kaiya)
dialogue.text: It was okay. Just a long day. Hey, I was thinking, you know how the animal shelter needs volunteers?

dialogue.speaker: Mom
dialogue.text: Yeah? Are you thinking about it?

dialogue.speaker: You (Kaiya)
dialogue.text: Maybe. It'd be a good way to stay busy, and Coach says stuff like that shows discipline.

dialogue.speaker: Sarah
dialogue.text: Hey, Kaiya, right? From English? I'm totally lost, is Mr. Davis's room this way?

dialogue.speaker: You (Kaiya)
dialogue.text: Oh, no, it's all the way on the other side of the building. You have to go down those stairs and take a left.

dialogue.speaker: Sarah
dialogue.text: Of course it is. This school is a maze. Thanks!

dialogue.speaker: You (Kaiya)
dialogue.text: No problem. It took me like two weeks to figure it out.

enrichments.baseline_profile_snippet: Your name is Ethan.  You are 14 years old. You are male. You are in 9th grade. You are not Hispanic or Latino. You identify as American Indian or Alaska Native, White. Your height without shoes is 1.7...

enriched_domains.overall_domain_narrative: School hallways are just background noise, a place where friends might jokingly try to pull you into their phone video while you're on your way to a class like entrepreneurship. You move through these moments easily enough, even if you're not always sure how close you feel to everyone. Your regular appointments with a therapist are helping you understand how your own brain works, putting a name to why you can feel a bit disconnected even when nothing bad is happening. It’s just a new piece of information you're learning to carry, separate from the everyday calm of your school and home life.

You walk through the school hallways, which feel more like a backdrop than a social gauntlet; it's a safe, neutral space where you might joke with a teammate about practice. You don't really feel sad or down because your phone provides a constant connection to people, a steady stream of memes and plans that keeps loneliness at bay. Operating on only five hours of sleep, your days can feel a bit hazy, and while you're not sure if you feel close to people at school, you always have your online world to plug into.

Your world is largely internal, even when you're surrounded by classmates in the hallway. You're more likely to be replaying the long conversation with your strength trainer about burnout and proper rest than listening to weekend plans. This intense focus on your athletic goals provides a shield; the idea of drinking or vaping doesn't even register as a temptation because it's completely irrelevant to your mission of gaining weight and improving your performance. In your mind, substances are just static, easily tuned out in favor of the much louder thoughts about your training, your grades, and what you talked about at your recent doctor's visits.

You scroll through social media several times a day, but it often feels like you're just watching other people's lives, finding it hard to get your real feelings across in a comment or DM. You sometimes wish it wasn't a thing, so you could just hang out with your friends and play basketball, where interactions feel more direct and less complicated. In school, you're present for the friendly chaos, like when classmates were joking around while making cookies, but you're more of an observer, not quite sure how to jump into the banter. The world of dating and relationships feels distant, like a conversation happening in another room that you're not a part of yet.

You're focused on gaining weight—muscle, really—for your spot on the team, but you're starting to feel burnt out from the constant activity and only five hours of sleep a night. After a long talk with your coach, you finally understand the importance of rest and having a real plan instead of just going through the motions in the weight room. Now, as you blend one of your daily protein smoothies in the kitchen after school, you decide to research better workout routines online, determined to train smarter, not just harder.

dialogue.speaker: Leo
dialogue.text: Yo, you hitting the weight room after school? I'm trying to max out my bench.

dialogue.speaker: You (Ethan)
dialogue.text: Nah, man. Coach and I talked. I'm supposed to actually rest today. Trying to train smarter.

dialogue.speaker: Leo
dialogue.text: For real? You're always grinding.

dialogue.speaker: You (Ethan)
dialogue.text: Yeah, that's the problem. My brain is fried from only getting like, five hours of sleep. I'll see you at practice tomorrow.

dialogue.speaker: Parent
dialogue.text: Another protein shake? Don't forget there are leftover baked potatoes from last night if you want some actual carbs.

dialogue.speaker: You (Ethan)
dialogue.text: Thanks. Just need to get this in first. Still trying to put on five pounds of muscle.

dialogue.speaker: Parent
dialogue.text: I get it. Just remember your biology grade slipped to a C. We need to focus on that, too.

dialogue.speaker: You (Ethan)
dialogue.text: I know. I'll work on it. It's just hard to focus when I'm so tired all the time.

dialogue.speaker: Maya
dialogue.text: weekend plans?? sarah's parents are out of town 👀

dialogue.speaker: Sam
dialogue.text: I'm there. Ethan, you gotta come.

dialogue.speaker: You (Ethan)
dialogue.text: Probably not. I have that early morning game and I need to sleep.

dialogue.speaker: Maya
dialogue.text: Lame! But okay, your loss. Bring us back a win.

daily_conversations.setting: Entrepreneurship class, working on a group project

dialogue.speaker: Chloe
dialogue.text: Okay, so I think our target audience for the custom cookie business is other students. What do you think, Ethan?

dialogue.speaker: You (Ethan)
dialogue.text: Huh? Oh, sorry. What was the question?

dialogue.speaker: Chloe
dialogue.text: The target audience. For the project.

dialogue.speaker: You (Ethan)
dialogue.text: Oh. Yeah, other students. That makes sense. Sounds good.

daily_conversations.setting: In the car, driving home from an appointment

dialogue.speaker: Parent
dialogue.text: How was your session with Dr. Evans?

dialogue.speaker: You (Ethan)
dialogue.text: It was fine. We just talked about stuff.

dialogue.speaker: Parent
dialogue.text: Okay. Well, we're here if you ever want to talk about the 'stuff'.

dialogue.speaker: You (Ethan)
dialogue.text: I know. Thanks. Can we just listen to music?

enrichments.baseline_profile_snippet: Your name is Lucas. You are 17 years old. You are male. You are in 12th grade. You are not Hispanic or Latino. You identify as Asian, White. Your height without shoes is 1.70 meters. Your weight witho...

enriched_domains.overall_domain_narrative: Your mornings are predictable and calm; you grab your bag and call out, 'See you later, Mom,' before heading out the door for school. At school, the hallways are just a backdrop for catching up with friends from your sports team, and any 'conflict' is usually just a debate over weekend plans in the group chat. You feel secure enough to focus on the future, practicing how to explain your leadership on the team and your good grades in mock interviews for college scholarships. The idea of a physical fight or feeling unsafe is completely foreign, something that doesn't register in your day-to-day world.

Your days feel full and productive, like the one where you finished a team lift and then spent nearly an hour just talking with your strength coach. The conversation shifted from workout routines to more personal things, and the coach's perspective gave you a lot to think about, making you re-evaluate your approach to your goals. You process these moments of self-discovery calmly, understanding that new insights about yourself are just information, not a label that defines you. This balanced perspective allows you to move through your school day feeling grounded and connected to others, whether you're joking with friends in the hall or getting dinner with family friends.

You navigate school and social life with a clear focus on your health and athletic goals, which naturally steers you clear of substances. You find yourself replaying the long conversation with your strength coach, newly committed to optimizing your routine and getting proper rest to avoid burnout. This intense focus isn't something you feel the need to explain or defend; you've come to understand it’s just how you're wired, and you know that being 'the disciplined athlete' doesn't define your whole identity any more than a specific diagnosis would.

In group chats or hallways, when friends talk about dating or who likes whom, you're more of a quiet observer. You listen without judgment as people figure themselves out, understanding that a label is just one part of a person, not their whole story. While you're not focused on dating right now, you approach the idea of a future relationship with the same dedication you give your studies and sports. You imagine it as a partnership built on teamwork and a shared work ethic, something you'll be ready for when the time is right.

You're trying to gain weight, but for you, that means building muscle for your sport, which has you on a demanding schedule. Your days are packed with early morning workouts before school, team practice, and then an afternoon lift, leaving you feeling both exhausted and accomplished. After a long talk with your coach about avoiding burnout, you've started focusing more on the 'why' behind your training and the importance of rest. This new perspective makes you more mindful of your nutrition, trying to fuel your body correctly, even if it's just by remembering to eat breakfast every day and drink more water.

daily_conversations.setting: School weight room after team practice

dialogue.speaker: Leo
dialogue.text: Man, I'm wiped. Are you really doing another set? I think I'm gonna tap out.

dialogue.speaker: You (Lucas)
dialogue.text: Yeah, just a quick one. Coach was talking to me about burnout, though. He said rest is as important as the lift. You should probably listen to your body.

dialogue.speaker: Leo
dialogue.text: True. Alright, I'm hitting the showers. See you tomorrow.

dialogue.speaker: You (Lucas)
dialogue.text: See ya.

dialogue.speaker: Maya
dialogue.text: Okay did anyone else see Chloe and Sam talking by the lockers? Looked intense.

dialogue.speaker: Ben
dialogue.text: omg i did!!! spill

dialogue.speaker: You (Lucas)
dialogue.text: Hey guys, quick question - for the history project, are we citing sources in APA or MLA? Can't find it on the sheet.

dialogue.speaker: Maya
dialogue.text: lol lucas always on task. it's APA

dialogue.speaker: Mom
dialogue.text: Morning, sweetie. You're up early again. Want your usual breakfast?

dialogue.speaker: You (Lucas)
dialogue.text: Morning. Yeah, eggs would be great, thanks. Trying to make sure I'm getting enough fuel for two-a-days.

dialogue.speaker: Mom
dialogue.text: Coming right up. Don't forget to grab a water bottle, you finished all the ones in the fridge yesterday.

daily_conversations.setting: School library during a free period

dialogue.speaker: Anna
dialogue.text: How's the big scholarship essay coming along? I'm so stuck on mine.

dialogue.speaker: You (Lucas)
dialogue.text: It’s getting there. I'm trying to write about leadership on the team without it sounding super cliché. It's harder than I thought.

dialogue.speaker: Anna
dialogue.text: I feel that. Good luck, you've got this.

dialogue.speaker: You (Lucas)
dialogue.text: Thanks, you too.

dialogue.speaker: Jake
dialogue.text: Hey, you survived Davis's pop quiz?

dialogue.speaker: You (Lucas)
dialogue.text: I think so? It was rough. At least it's over. You heading to lunch?

dialogue.speaker: Jake
dialogue.text: Yeah, let's go. I'm starving.

enrichments.baseline_profile_snippet: Your name is Maya. You are 16 years old. You are female. You are in 11th grade. You are not Hispanic or Latino. You identify as Black or African American. Your height without shoes is 1.63 meters. You...

enriched_domains.overall_domain_narrative: You experience your world as a fundamentally safe place, where school hallways are for laughing with friends, not looking over your shoulder. Lunch breaks are spent rating your day based on your class schedule and showing off your tray of salad and oranges, the conversation light and easy. The most stressful part of your commute isn't a threat of violence, but the mundane frustration of an unexpected road closure making you late for first period. This sense of security is your normal, a stark contrast to the dangers you know exist but haven't personally had to face.

Your school days feel straightforward and secure, marked by easy camaraderie with your friends. During lunch, you sit together rating your morning classes, the conversation light and untroubled. When a friend mentions a summer job opening, you find yourself confidently explaining how your academic achievements and daily fitness routine have given you a strong work ethic, even without formal job experience. Your mind feels clear and capable, easily shifting between casual chatter and thoughts about your future ambitions.

You're heading to lunch with your friends, laughing as you all do a 'fit check' for social media and rate the day's classes so far. You grab a salad instead of pizza, a choice that feels good even if you know you'll probably have a soda later. The conversation is easy, flowing from homework to weekend plans, completely separate from the world of the party where you had a drink a few weeks ago. In these everyday moments at school, your focus is on your friends and your grades; substances just aren't part of this picture.

You see one of your exes in the hallway between classes, and the interaction is surprisingly normal, just a quick, friendly 'what's up'. It's easier in person; you remember how frustrating it was when you two were dating and a simple text could get twisted into a whole argument. You've learned that things get lost in translation over the phone and that navigating relationships means knowing when to put the screen down. Now, you prefer keeping conversations light in your group chats, sticking to memes and homework help instead of anything that could be misinterpreted.

Your daily 60-minute workout is a non-negotiable part of your routine, a focused time that makes you feel strong and in control. At school, you feel confident and at ease with your friends, but you also find yourself scrolling through social media during a free period, comparing your body to others and feeling that familiar pressure to be leaner. This feeling is why you're 'trying to lose weight,' even though a part of you thinks you're fine, and it's what makes you skip breakfast and grab a soda from the vending machine instead of water.

dialogue.speaker: Chloe
dialogue.text: Are you really getting the salad again? I'm going for the pizza, I'm starving.

dialogue.speaker: You (Maya)
dialogue.text: Yeah, I'm trying to be good. Plus, I skipped breakfast so this is my one big meal before my workout later.

dialogue.speaker: Chloe
dialogue.text: Fair. So a soda to go with your healthy salad?

dialogue.speaker: You (Maya)
dialogue.text: Hey, it's all about balance, right?

dialogue.speaker: Liam
dialogue.text: Party at Kevin's this weekend. Who's in?

dialogue.speaker: Zoe
dialogue.text: ME! Is it gonna be big?

dialogue.speaker: You (Maya)
dialogue.text: Maybe. Depends on the ride situation. That drive home from the last one was a little sketchy.

dialogue.speaker: Liam
dialogue.text: Word. We'll get a designated driver this time for sure.

dialogue.speaker: You (Maya)
dialogue.text: Okay cool, keep me posted. I might just need a chill weekend anyway.

dialogue.speaker: David
dialogue.text: Ugh, I am not ready for this physics test. My brain is fried.

dialogue.speaker: You (Maya)
dialogue.text: I know, it’s a lot. I feel like my 6 AM run is the only thing that gets my head clear enough to study for it.

dialogue.speaker: David
dialogue.text: You're a machine. I can barely get out of bed for school.

dialogue.speaker: You (Maya)
dialogue.text: It's my routine! If I can get through that, I feel like I can handle anything, even Mr. Harrison's equations.

daily_conversations.setting: During a free period in the library

dialogue.speaker: Aisha
dialogue.text: What are you scrolling for? You look intense.

dialogue.speaker: You (Maya)
dialogue.text: Oh, nothing. Just looking at workout vids. I feel like I need to switch things up.

dialogue.speaker: Aisha
dialogue.text: Why? You're literally the most fit person I know.

dialogue.speaker: You (Maya)
dialogue.text: I don't know. I just see all these girls online and feel like I could be... leaner, I guess. It's stupid.

dialogue.speaker: Mark
dialogue.text: Hey, Maya. What's up?

dialogue.speaker: You (Maya)
dialogue.text: Oh, hey. Not much, just trying to survive junior year. You?

dialogue.speaker: Mark
dialogue.text: Same. Hey, sorry again about all that drama before. I was weird over text.

dialogue.speaker: You (Maya)
dialogue.text: It's all good. Honestly, I've learned to just not have serious talks over the phone anymore. It never works.

enrichments.baseline_profile_snippet: Your name is Jaden. You are 14 years old. You are male. You are in 9th grade. You are not Hispanic or Latino. You identify as Black or African American. Your height without shoes is 1.68 meters. Your ...

enriched_domains.overall_domain_narrative: Despite being threatened at school and seeing violence in your neighborhood, you navigate your days by focusing on the normal parts, the moments that make you feel connected. You'll pull out your phone to start a 'vlog' walking into school, laughing as your friend tries to duck out of the frame before you all head to class to make cookies. But even a simple traffic jam can put you on edge, making you anxious about being late because a cop blocked the road, a situation that feels out of your control and reminds you of being disciplined unfairly in the past. These moments are your routine: finding pockets of fun with people you trust while a quiet, watchful part of you stays on guard.

Even when you're with friends and everything seems fine, a strange disconnect can take over. You're in a group chat watching people make weekend plans, but their normal happiness makes you feel even more isolated with the sadness that made you consider suicide this past year. A heavy numbness settles in, and you just don't care about the jokes or plans because your own thoughts are so overwhelming. You're physically there, part of the group, but mentally and emotionally, you feel a million miles away.

You scroll through your phone, seeing posts from parties over the weekend, but it feels distant; while you’ve had a drink before, it’s not really your scene and you find it hard to connect with people through a screen. You'd rather be doing something real, like working on your goal to gain weight, and you think about the conversation you had with a school coach about workout routines, which really helped you focus. This goal gives you something to control when other things feel off, making it easier to turn down offers to drink or smoke because you don't want to mess with your progress.

At the lunch table with your friends, you feel a sense of ease, rating your day a solid '6 out of 10' as you try to finish everything on your tray to gain weight. The easy banter is a welcome distraction from the low-grade sadness that sometimes follows you and the memory of being treated badly because of your race in class earlier. When a girl you know stops by the table, you just shrug and give a small smile, feeling a little awkward and unsure of what to say. It's easier to just focus on your friends, pushing away thoughts about your past relationships and the risks you took.

You're determined to stop being what you see as "very underweight," so you've been researching how to gain muscle online after school. After watching a video about workout burnout, you realize why you've been feeling so exhausted: you haven't been getting proper rest or focusing on the 'why' behind your exercises. Standing in the kitchen, you blend a protein smoothie, hoping this new, more informed approach is the key to finally making a change you can see and feel.

dialogue.speaker: Jaden
dialogue.text: Alright, vlog entry number... I don't know, 30? We're heading into English. Say hi to my millions of followers, Maya.

dialogue.speaker: Maya
dialogue.text: Stop! I look so tired. Get that thing away from me.

dialogue.speaker: Jaden
dialogue.text: Too late, you're a star now. Okay, for real though...
dialogue.action: He lowers his phone as he sees a school security guard down the hall.

dialogue.speaker: Jaden
dialogue.text: Let's just get to class before the bell.

dialogue.speaker: Liam
dialogue.text: Yo, who's pulling up to Kevin's party Friday? Heard it's gonna be huge.

dialogue.speaker: Chloe
dialogue.text: MEEEE! Finally, something to do.

dialogue.speaker: Jaden
dialogue.text: Nah, I'm good.

dialogue.speaker: Liam
dialogue.text: Lame. Why not?

dialogue.speaker: Jaden
dialogue.text: Just feelin tired. Probably just gonna do a workout and chill.

dialogue.speaker: Leo
dialogue.text: Bro, are you seriously eating another sandwich? That's your second one.

dialogue.speaker: Jaden
dialogue.text: Trying to. Gotta get my calories up. I'm tired of being so skinny.

dialogue.speaker: Sarah
dialogue.text: Hey Jaden, hey Leo.

dialogue.speaker: Jaden
dialogue.text: Hey.
dialogue.action: He gives a small nod and a slight smile before focusing back on his food.

dialogue.speaker: Mom
dialogue.text: What is all this stuff you're blending? Is that another one of those shakes?

dialogue.speaker: Jaden
dialogue.text: Yeah, it's just protein. For after my workout. I'll clean the blender when I'm done.

dialogue.speaker: Mom
dialogue.text: You're so obsessed with this weight thing. I hope you're not overdoing it.

dialogue.speaker: Jaden
dialogue.text: I'm not. I watched a video about burnout. It's about working out smart and resting, not just doing it all the time.

dialogue.speaker: Coach Davis
dialogue.text: Hey Jaden, how's that routine we talked about treating you?

dialogue.speaker: Jaden
dialogue.text: It's good. Definitely feel it the next day.

dialogue.speaker: Coach Davis
dialogue.text: That's what we want! Just remember what I said about rest days. That's when you actually get stronger.

dialogue.speaker: Jaden
dialogue.text: Yeah, I remember. Trying to get more sleep, too. Thanks, coach.

enrichments.baseline_profile_snippet: Your name is Nia. You are 15 years old. You are female. You are in 10th grade. You are not Hispanic or Latino. You identify as Black or African American, Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander. You...

enriched_domains.overall_domain_narrative: You navigate the crowded high school hallways, a space that feels vast and impersonal, much bigger than middle school. Since you don't have classes with your main friend group, you often feel a bit disconnected until you can all meet up during the long lunch period. Even in these ordinary moments, you find yourself on guard, replaying past instances of being unfairly disciplined or treated badly because of your race, which makes it hard to fully relax. The constant noise and shifting class schedules often overwhelm your ability to concentrate, leaving you feeling drained even on days when nothing overtly bad happens.

In class, the teacher's voice fades into a low hum, and even when a friend makes a joke in the hallway, it feels like it's happening behind a pane of glass. The sadness is a heavy, numbing blanket that makes it hard to feel anything else, and you often find yourself just nodding along, unable to connect. This feeling follows you home, where you might look in the mirror and not recognize the tired person staring back, remembering you haven't brushed your teeth all week and just not having the energy to care. It hits you then that this isn't right, this isn't you, but you don't know how to change it.

In neutral settings like a group chat or the school library, your decision to not use substances is a quiet anchor for you. While you observe others making different choices, you find your own space by focusing on structured activities, like a regular volunteer shift at the animal shelter. This commitment gives you a sense of purpose and helps you build skills, like responsibility and teamwork, that feel more valuable than fitting in at a party. It's a way for you to feel in control and dedicated to something positive when other parts of your life feel difficult.

You're not sure if you feel close to people at school, but you have your small circle of real friends. In your group chat, you're not just 'the trans girl'; you're the one who finds the best reaction memes and actually understands the chemistry homework. It’s a relief to have friends who don't care that you're different and who see all of you without making your identity the main event. This space allows you to just be Nia, which feels more normal than anything else.

Lunchtime feels like a balancing act; you grab carrots and fruit but also a soda, trying to keep things steady just like your weight. You sit with a couple of classmates, but as they chat about their morning, your focus drifts to your phone. Scrolling through social media feels more manageable than trying to keep up with the conversation, creating a quiet bubble for you in the loud cafeteria.

dialogue.speaker: Liam
dialogue.text: I'm gonna fail this chem test tomorrow. I don't get titration at all.

dialogue.speaker: Chloe
dialogue.text: SAME. I stared at the textbook for an hour and nothing.

dialogue.speaker: You (Nia)
dialogue.text: *sends a GIF of a cat frantically pushing beakers off a lab bench*

dialogue.speaker: You (Nia)
dialogue.text: It's basically just finding the unknown concentration. The formula on page 87 is all you need. M1V1 = M2V2.

dialogue.speaker: Liam
dialogue.text: You're a lifesaver, Nia.

dialogue.speaker: Maya
dialogue.text: Hey, that new Marvel trailer looks insane, right? Are you gonna see it opening weekend?

dialogue.speaker: You (Nia)
dialogue.text: (Looks up from phone, takes a sip of soda) Oh, yeah. Maybe. I hadn't really thought about it.

dialogue.speaker: Maya
dialogue.text: We should get a group to go! It'll be fun.

dialogue.speaker: You (Nia)
dialogue.text: Hm. Yeah, maybe. (Gives a small nod and eyes drift back to phone screen.)

dialogue.speaker: Mr. Davis
dialogue.text: Nia, can I see you for a sec? I noticed you were kind of zoned out during the discussion today.

dialogue.speaker: You (Nia)
dialogue.text: Oh. Sorry. I guess I'm just tired. I didn't get a lot of sleep.

dialogue.speaker: Mr. Davis
dialogue.text: I get it. Just wanted to make sure everything's okay. The reading logs are due Friday, but let me know if you need an extension.

dialogue.speaker: You (Nia)
dialogue.text: Okay. Thanks, Mr. Davis.

dialogue.speaker: Parent
dialogue.text: Where are you going?

dialogue.speaker: You (Nia)
dialogue.text: To the animal shelter. My volunteer shift.

dialogue.speaker: Parent
dialogue.text: Don't forget your keys. Be back by six.

dialogue.speaker: You (Nia)
dialogue.text: I know. I will.

daily_conversations.setting: Animal Shelter, in the cat enclosure

dialogue.speaker: Ben
dialogue.text: Can you help me with this new kitten? He won't eat and just hides.

dialogue.speaker: You (Nia)
dialogue.text: Yeah, of course. Let's try the wet food. Sometimes if you just sit quietly with them for a bit, they'll come out. Don't try to grab him.

dialogue.speaker: Ben
dialogue.text: Okay, good idea. You're really good with the shy ones.

dialogue.speaker: You (Nia)
dialogue.text: (Gives a small, genuine smile) They're my favorite.

enrichments.baseline_profile_snippet: Your name is Hana. You are 16 years old. You are female. You are in 10th grade. You are not Hispanic or Latino. You identify as Asian. Your height without shoes is 1.65 meters. Your weight without sho...

enriched_domains.overall_domain_narrative: Even in a quiet classroom, your mind isn't at peace; you're constantly bracing for the anger you'll face at home over your 'mostly B's,' a fear you know well from past report cards. You see teachers who try to be friendly and liked, but you keep your distance, having learned that emotional closeness often leads to disappointment or hurt. While you feel physically safe walking the school halls, you remain disconnected from the easy laughter and chatter of your classmates, an invisible wall separating you from their world.

You walk through the school hallways, a space that seems friendly for everyone else, but for you, it's like watching a movie with the sound turned down. The overwhelming sadness you carry creates a barrier, making you feel numb and disconnected from the laughter and light jokes around you. When the loneliness becomes too much, you turn to your phone, scrolling through social media and sending messages to friends, a small attempt to feel less alone in a world where you feel so separate. Even in class, your difficulty concentrating makes the teacher's voice a distant drone, as your thoughts are consumed by a fog that makes nothing else seem to matter.
No relevant neutral environment experiences found for this domain.

You see couples in the school hallways, their interactions looking awkward and unenthusiastic, and it just reinforces your feeling of being completely disconnected from everyone. You don't feel envious, just empty, as if you're watching a show you don't understand. At home, you scroll through social media and watch clips from old 80s movies, wishing for a relationship that felt grand and safe, with someone who put in real effort. This fantasy feels much safer than thinking about your actual experiences with boys, which have been anything but romantic.

Although you tell yourself you're at the right weight, you are trying to lose some, partly influenced by the social media you scroll through late at night. Those hours feel like the only free time you have, even though you know it's why you only get five hours of sleep and struggle to concentrate in school. To feel more in control, you look up core workouts online after being active, wanting to do more for recovery than just stopping your exercise. These small efforts, like eating a salad every day and avoiding soda, are quiet acts of taking care of yourself when you don't feel close to anyone.

dialogue.speaker: Liam
dialogue.text: Hey, that history lecture was brutal, right? I almost fell asleep.

dialogue.speaker: Hana (You)
dialogue.text: Oh. Yeah, I guess.

dialogue.speaker: Liam
dialogue.text: You going to the game on Friday night?

dialogue.speaker: Hana (You)
dialogue.text: No. I have stuff to do.

dialogue.speaker: Ms. Davis
dialogue.text: Hana, can I have a quick word? You seemed a bit distant during the discussion today. Is everything alright?

dialogue.speaker: Hana (You)
dialogue.text: I'm fine. Just tired.

dialogue.speaker: Ms. Davis
dialogue.text: Okay. Well, try to get some rest. And don't forget the reading for tomorrow.

dialogue.speaker: Hana (You)
dialogue.text: I won't.

dialogue.speaker: Chloe
dialogue.text: Movie night at my place Saturday? We can watch that new horror flick.

dialogue.speaker: Ben
dialogue.text: I'm so down! 🍿

dialogue.speaker: Chloe
dialogue.text: Hana, you in?

dialogue.speaker: Hana (You)
dialogue.text: Can't. My parents are really strict about weekends.

dialogue.speaker: Maya
dialogue.text: Another salad, Hana? You're so disciplined.

dialogue.speaker: Hana (You)
dialogue.text: It's just what I packed.

dialogue.speaker: Maya
dialogue.text: I wish. This mystery meat is probably going to haunt me later.

dialogue.speaker: Hana (You)
dialogue.text: Probably.

dialogue.speaker: Leo
dialogue.text: Did you see Mr. Carter trip over the projector cord today? I thought I was going to die laughing.

dialogue.speaker: Hana (You)
dialogue.text: When was that?

dialogue.speaker: Leo
dialogue.text: Like, middle of third period! He almost took the whole screen down with him.

dialogue.speaker: Hana (You)
dialogue.text: Oh. I must have been looking at my notes.

enrichments.baseline_profile_snippet: Your name is Mateo. You are 18 years old or older. You are male. You are in 12th grade. You are Hispanic or Latino. You identify as American Indian or Alaska Native. Your height without shoes is 1.70 ...

enriched_domains.overall_domain_narrative: You feel physically safe at school, but your difficulty concentrating makes the crowded hallways feel distant, as if you're watching a movie. You remember posting a school picture online with a dark joke that you immediately regretted when the administration called you in; it was a stark lesson in how quickly a 'dumb' joke could be misinterpreted as a threat. Seeing tight-knit groups like the band celebrating their wins makes you feel your own social disconnect more sharply. These experiences remind you that even in a place free from physical fights, danger feels present—whether it's one wrong post or the decision to accept a ride from someone who has been drinking.

You walk through the school hallways feeling like you’re behind a glass wall, hearing the chatter and laughter of other students as if from a great distance. When friends talk about their weekend plans, you feel a profound sense of isolation, as their normal happiness only amplifies how sad and hopeless you feel inside. Because you have trouble concentrating, your mind often drifts during conversations, and the anhedonia makes it impossible to find real enjoyment in things you used to like. You find yourself just going through the motions, ruminating on why you feel so disconnected from everyone even when nothing is obviously wrong.

In the neutral spaces of school hallways or the gym, you often feel like you're just going through the motions, your head too full to fully connect. You pour your energy into workouts, but recently realized you're just doing things without knowing why, leaving you feeling burnt out and disconnected from your own body. The serious difficulty you have concentrating makes you sometimes wonder if there's a name for what you're experiencing, but you quickly decide that a label doesn't define who you are. Staying away from alcohol or marijuana isn't a big statement; it's just one less thing to have to process when your mind already feels so overloaded.

In the hallways or scrolling through group chats, you're usually quiet and keep to yourself, more of an observer than a participant. Your mind is often somewhere else, replaying a conversation about getting your workout routine right to avoid burnout, or just struggling against the fog of sadness and difficulty concentrating that follows you. When conversations turn to dating or sex, you feel a bit detached, quietly reminding yourself that this one part of life doesn't define your whole identity, especially when you have so much else to figure out.

Your days are a blur of pre-dawn alarms and high-intensity workouts, often leaving you rushing to school on four hours of sleep with your mind already hazy. Though you see your weight as about right, you've been pushing to get leaner, but lately, it feels like you're just going through the motions, which has led to a deep sense of burnout. A recent long talk with your PE teacher, who acts as a strength coach, was a breakthrough, making you realize you’ve been ignoring rest and training without a clear purpose. You feel a flicker of hope that by changing your routine to be smarter, not just harder, you can finally get your body and your head back in the game.

dialogue.speaker: Leo
dialogue.text: Man, you killed that workout. You hitting up that bonfire this weekend?

dialogue.speaker: Mateo
dialogue.text: Nah. Probably just gonna crash. I'm wiped.

dialogue.speaker: Leo
dialogue.text: Dude, you're always wiped. You gotta take a rest day sometime.

dialogue.speaker: Mateo
dialogue.text: Yeah. I know. My head's just... not really in it for parties right now.

dialogue.speaker: Jasmine
dialogue.text: Okay did anyone actually get question 5 on the worksheet? I'm totally lost.

dialogue.speaker: Carlos
dialogue.text: It's about the economic impact, check page 245. The chart helps.

dialogue.speaker: Jasmine
dialogue.text: OMG you're a lifesaver. Mateo, you good? You've been quiet.

dialogue.speaker: Mateo
dialogue.text: Yeah. Just reading.

dialogue.speaker: Mateo's Mom
dialogue.text: Mijo, you need to eat something more than just potatoes. You're working out so much.

dialogue.speaker: Mateo
dialogue.text: I'm not that hungry. I'm just gonna grab a soda and go do homework.

dialogue.speaker: Mateo's Mom
dialogue.text: You got home late. Were you with your uncle again?

dialogue.speaker: Mateo
dialogue.text: No, just at the gym. I'm fine. Just tired.

daily_conversations.setting: In the weight room after school

dialogue.speaker: Mr. Evans
dialogue.text: Lighter weight today, Mateo? Good. Remember what we talked about, focus on the form.

dialogue.speaker: Mateo
dialogue.text: Trying. It feels weird not just going until I'm totally burned out.

dialogue.speaker: Mr. Evans
dialogue.text: That's how you get stronger, not just more tired. It's a mental game, too. You look exhausted.

dialogue.speaker: Mateo
dialogue.text: Yeah. Didn't sleep much. But I'm trying this.

dialogue.speaker: Chloe
dialogue.text: So for the main character's motivation... what do you think, Mateo?

dialogue.speaker: Mateo
dialogue.text: Huh? Oh, sorry. I kinda zoned out. What was the question?

dialogue.speaker: Chloe
dialogue.text: It's all good. Just about why he does what he does. I was saying it seems like he feels disconnected from everyone.

dialogue.speaker: Mateo
dialogue.text: Yeah. Disconnected. That sounds right.

enrichments.baseline_profile_snippet: Your name is Diego. You are 15 years old. You are male. You are in 10th grade. You are not Hispanic or Latino. You identify as Asian. Your height without shoes is 1.68 meters. Your weight without shoe...

enriched_domains.overall_domain_narrative: Even supposedly neutral spaces feel charged with potential threats, making it hard to ever let your guard down. You climb the school roof not for the thrill of getting in trouble, but to find the one place where you can be alone and feel a moment of quiet away from the halls where you've been threatened and attacked. When a cop unexpectedly blocks the road, your frustration isn't about being late; it's a surge of pure anxiety, your mind immediately bracing for a confrontation you feel is inevitable.

You walk through the school hallways, but the lighthearted jokes and friendly chatter feel like they're happening behind a thick wall of glass. Even things that should be fun, like scrolling through memes in a group chat, bring no enjoyment, just a familiar, hollow feeling of loneliness. You've missed so much school and feel so disconnected that you keep to yourself, convinced that no one would know how to reach out or what to say even if they noticed you were struggling. This deepens your isolation, making you feel completely alone even when you're surrounded by people.

In supposedly neutral spaces like a classroom, your mind is a thick fog from the weed you use to get through each day, making it impossible to concentrate. You see other kids joking in the halls, but their laughter sounds distant and you remain on high alert, your hand drifting to the weapon in your pocket. You skip classes often, finding it easier to get high alone than to navigate social interactions that feel like a test you're doomed to fail. This need for escape continues at night as you sneak out your window, not even caring if you leave evidence of your escape behind.

You walk through school hallways trapped in a bubble, but it's not from shyness; it's a constant, tense scan for the next threat. When a PE teacher you barely know asks why you seem so burnt out, the question catches you off guard, as you're used to adults either ignoring or hurting you. You realize you're just doing things without knowing why—surviving, not living—and this brief, neutral conversation feels strangely quiet in your head. The moment ends, and the usual noise rushes back in, leaving you more confused than hopeful about what that quiet even meant.

You feel like the only time you get to yourself is late at night, scrolling endlessly on your phone when your house is finally quiet. It's an escape, but it leaves you with only a few hours of sleep, making it impossible to get up for breakfast. You often grab a soda during the day just for the sugar and caffeine rush to keep from nodding off in class, even though you know it's not helping you gain the weight you want.

dialogue.speaker: Sam
dialogue.text: Whoa, Diego, you look wrecked. You get any sleep last night?

dialogue.speaker: Diego
dialogue.text: Something like that.

dialogue.speaker: Sam
dialogue.text: Tell me about it. I was up until 2 AM grinding on that bio project. Mr. Harrison is brutal.

dialogue.speaker: Diego
dialogue.text: Yeah.

daily_conversations.setting: A group chat for a history class project.

dialogue.speaker: Liam
dialogue.text: Okay guys, we need to finish the slides for the presentation. I can do the intro and background.

dialogue.speaker: Chloe
dialogue.text: I'll take the main arguments. Diego, can you handle the conclusion and the 'impact' slide?

dialogue.speaker: Diego
dialogue.text: k

dialogue.speaker: Chloe
dialogue.text: Cool, thanks! Just try to get a draft in the doc by tonight so we can see it.

daily_conversations.setting: English classroom before the bell rings.

dialogue.speaker: Ms. Albright
dialogue.text: Diego, good to see you today. I noticed you've been out a bit. Is everything okay?

dialogue.speaker: Diego
dialogue.text: I'm fine.

dialogue.speaker: Ms. Albright
dialogue.text: Alright. Well, if you need to catch up on the missed work, my office hours are after school. I want to make sure you have a chance to pass.

dialogue.speaker: Diego
dialogue.text: Mhm.

dialogue.speaker: Jay
dialogue.text: Yo, Diego. Grabbing the essentials?

dialogue.speaker: Diego
dialogue.text: Need something to stay awake.

dialogue.speaker: Jay
dialogue.text: For real. Hey, a few of us are heading to the park to hang out, you should roll through.

dialogue.speaker: Diego
dialogue.text: Nah, I got stuff to do.

daily_conversations.setting: The kitchen at home, late at night.

dialogue.speaker: Diego's Guardian
dialogue.text: What are you doing up?

dialogue.speaker: Diego
dialogue.text: Getting a soda.

dialogue.speaker: Diego's Guardian
dialogue.text: You're always creeping around this house. Go to bed before you fail out of school completely.

enrichments.baseline_profile_snippet: Your name is Emily. You are 14 years old. You are female. You are in 9th grade. You are not Hispanic or Latino. You identify as White. Your height without shoes is 1.60 meters. Your weight without sho...

enriched_domains.overall_domain_narrative: Even in a quiet moment at home, you feel on edge, bracing for the next insult from the adult you live with. It reminds you of the fight you got into last year, not at school, but in your own house where an argument exploded and ended with a door kicked off its hinges. You've seen what happens when things escalate in your neighborhood, and you've been threatened with a weapon at school, so even neutral spaces don't feel safe. You're just waiting for the next conflict, whether it's a thrown object at home or a shove in the crowded school hallway.

You walk through the crowded, loud school hallways feeling completely separate from everyone, as if you're behind a glass wall. The laughter and chatter of other students feel distant and alien; you don't feel close to anyone here and have learned it's safer to be invisible. A simple question from a teacher or a look from a peer can feel like a personal attack, making it hard to breathe and impossible to focus. You often have to fight the urge to cry, searching for an empty bathroom stall or quiet corner to hide until the overwhelming feeling passes.

In the supposedly friendly school hallways, you keep your head down, the exhaustion from only four hours of sleep making everything feel blurry and distant. The chatter of other students feels like a language you don't speak, so you focus on getting to the bathroom to vape or just making it through another day feeling totally disconnected. Group chats buzz with homework questions you can't focus on and inside jokes you aren't a part of; your mind is either racing with anxiety or counting the hours until you can get a drink to numb the sadness. You've gotten good at slipping away, whether it's skipping a class you're already failing or leaving a window open late at night, viewing it as a necessary risk to quiet the noise in your head.
No relevant neutral environment experiences found for this domain.

The lunch bell rings, and you wander through the huge, noisy cafeteria, feeling invisible. Even though you haven't eaten since yesterday, the thought of food makes your stomach churn, so you just sip on a sports drink you bought from the vending machine. You see some of your teammates from the fall season laughing at a table, but you keep your head down and find an empty spot outside, pulling out your phone to distract yourself from the hunger. You tell yourself skipping one more meal is part of the plan to lose weight, even though a part of you knows you're already small enough.

dialogue.speaker: Sarah
dialogue.text: Hey Emily! Thank god it's almost Friday, right? This week has been killer.

dialogue.speaker: Emily
dialogue.text: Yeah. Sure.

dialogue.speaker: Sarah
dialogue.text: You going to the game tonight?

dialogue.speaker: Emily
dialogue.text: No. I have to do something. See you.

dialogue.speaker: Mr. Harrison
dialogue.text: Emily, head up. You look a million miles away today.

dialogue.speaker: Emily
dialogue.text: Sorry. I'm just tired.

dialogue.speaker: Mr. Harrison
dialogue.text: I get it, but I need you with us. We're reviewing for the test. Your grades could use a bump.

dialogue.speaker: Emily
dialogue.text: Okay.

daily_conversations.setting: A group chat for a science project

dialogue.speaker: Liam
dialogue.text: Did anyone finish their part of the slideshow? It's due Thursday.

dialogue.speaker: Chloe
dialogue.text: Almost! Just have to add pics. Btw did u guys see that new TikTok dance? It's impossible lol

dialogue.speaker: Liam
dialogue.text: The one with the weird arm thing? Yeah my sister tried it and fell 😂

dialogue.speaker: Chloe
dialogue.text: Emily u should try it, you were on the dance team right?

dialogue.speaker: Emily
dialogue.text: That was last year. My phone's about to die, gotta go.

dialogue.speaker: Jess
dialogue.text: Emily! Hey! I haven't seen you around. You trying out for spring soccer?

dialogue.speaker: Emily
dialogue.text: Nah. Not this year.

dialogue.speaker: Jess
dialogue.text: What? Why not? We need you! Are you okay? You look kinda... thin.

dialogue.speaker: Emily
dialogue.text: I'm fine. Just don't feel like it.

dialogue.speaker: Adult in Home
dialogue.text: Where were you?

dialogue.speaker: Emily
dialogue.text: School.

dialogue.speaker: Adult in Home
dialogue.text: Don't get smart. I got another email about your grades. Are you even trying?

dialogue.speaker: Emily
dialogue.text: Whatever.

enrichments.baseline_profile_snippet: Your name is Amara. You are 16 years old. You are female. You are in 9th grade. You are not Hispanic or Latino. You identify as American Indian or Alaska Native, Asian, Black or African American, Nati...

enriched_domains.overall_domain_narrative: You lean against the lockers as friends chat nearby, the noise of the hallway a dull roar in your ears. Even when a classmate makes a friendly joke, you can only manage a small nod, feeling the familiar weight of exhaustion that makes smiling feel impossible. The memory of being treated badly because of your race makes you flinch internally at any loud voice, wanting to cover your ears and just make it all stop. You feel a sudden, overwhelming urge to just go home and sleep for weeks, a desperate wish to escape the effort of pretending you're okay.

Even when the school hallways are friendly, you often feel a profound numbness, a heavy blanket of sadness that makes it impossible to feel anything else. When your friends try to include you in group chats about memes or homework, you find it hard to concentrate, the words blurring together as your thoughts drift. The effort to participate is so exhausting that sometimes all you want to do is go home and sleep for weeks, just to make the overwhelming feelings stop.

In neutral spaces like a group chat about homework, you try to play the part, sending back a laughing emoji at a meme your friend shared. Your phone is a double-edged sword; you scroll constantly through feeds that would shock your parents, a world of content reflecting the chaos you feel inside. When friends talk about weekend plans, your mind drifts to your own version of escape: sneaking out the window, leaving a clumsy trail of evidence as you did before, just to get a ride and use marijuana somewhere far from home. These moments of quiet connection with friends are a thin veil over the risks you take to cope with the noise in your head and your house.

You sit with your friends at lunch, the noise of the cafeteria a welcome distraction from the exhaustion that clings to you after another sleepless night. When your friend asks you to rate your day, you struggle for a moment to remember your morning classes, your mind feeling foggy and distant. You mumble something about a “six out of ten,” but when another friend playfully compliments your new hoodie, you look down, a rare, shy smile touching your lips. For a second, you feel a flicker of warmth you don't quite know how to hold onto before you pull your phone out to scroll.

You're trying to lose weight, but it feels like an uphill battle when you're running on only a few hours of sleep. In PE class, you hate when it's pickleball day; you just stand there, feeling exhausted and self-conscious, wishing the period would end. Later, you'll pull out your phone to look up easy workouts, but get sidetracked scrolling through social media, which only makes you feel more hopeless about your body. It's easier to just grab a soda than to think about eating the fruits or vegetables you know you're supposed to have.

dialogue.speaker: Maya
dialogue.text: Hey. How's your day on a scale of one to ten?

dialogue.speaker: You (Amara)
dialogue.text: Mmm... a four? I don't know. I can't really remember this morning.

dialogue.speaker: Maya
dialogue.text: That bad? Well, I like your hoodie. The color is cool.

dialogue.speaker: You (Amara)
dialogue.text: Oh. Thanks.

dialogue.speaker: Leo
dialogue.text: You wanna go to the library after school? We could start that history project.

dialogue.speaker: You (Amara)
dialogue.text: Uh, I don't know. I'm really tired. Maybe.

dialogue.speaker: Leo
dialogue.text: Okay, well, text me if you change your mind.

dialogue.speaker: You (Amara)
dialogue.text: Yeah. Okay.

dialogue.speaker: Chloe
dialogue.text: [sends a funny video of a dog failing to catch a ball]

dialogue.speaker: Sam
dialogue.text: LMAO that's literally me trying to do physics homework.

dialogue.speaker: Chloe
dialogue.text: Right?? Btw did you guys watch the new episode of Starfall? It was insane.

dialogue.speaker: You (Amara)
dialogue.text: lol

daily_conversations.setting: The school gym during PE class

dialogue.speaker: Kevin
dialogue.text: Amara, you're up! Come on, my team needs a point!

dialogue.speaker: You (Amara)
dialogue.text: I'm good. You guys can go without me.

dialogue.speaker: Kevin
dialogue.text: But it's pickleball, you just stand there. Just try.

dialogue.speaker: You (Amara)
dialogue.text: I just... I don't feel good.

daily_conversations.setting: Waiting for the bus after school

dialogue.speaker: Jayla
dialogue.text: You going to Kyle's party this weekend? Heard it's gonna be big.

dialogue.speaker: You (Amara)
dialogue.text: Maybe. Who's driving?

dialogue.speaker: Jayla
dialogue.text: I don't know, probably Liam or someone. Why?

dialogue.speaker: You (Amara)
dialogue.text: Just wondering.

enrichments.baseline_profile_snippet: Your name is Tavian. You are 17 years old. You are male. You are in 11th grade. You are not Hispanic or Latino. You identify as American Indian or Alaska Native, Asian, Black or African American, Nati...

enriched_domains.overall_domain_narrative: You walk through the seemingly neutral school hallways like a ghost, the chatter and laughter of other students a language you don't speak. You skip classes constantly, finding it easier to just disappear from the building than to endure the feeling of being watched and judged. On the rare days you try to engage, your humor, darkened by your reality, falls flat; a sarcastic joke about your school photo looking like a mugshot earns you wary stares, not laughs, reinforcing why you stay away.

You move through the school hallways as if underwater, the sounds of classmates laughing and talking feeling muffled and distant. It's a state where you just don't care, a mindset where nothing else matters because the sadness is so overwhelming that you can't feel anything else. This profound loneliness is the most debilitating part, making it impossible to enjoy even neutral moments, as your mind struggles to concentrate or simply goes blank.

You walk through the school halls between classes, but the chatter of other students feels like it's happening in a different world from which you are completely disconnected. You often skip class, not for fun, but to find a quiet corner behind the gym or an empty bathroom to get high. Using is just a habit now, a neutral action you take throughout the day to quiet the noise in your head and numb the constant feeling of being on edge. It's the only way you know how to create a moment of calm for yourself before facing whatever comes next.

When your girlfriend corners you in the hall for a video, you just mumble that you don't want to be in it, feeling the familiar exhaustion from lack of sleep and the difficulty of concentrating on anything. Even in this seemingly lighthearted moment, a knot forms in your stomach, as her demands often escalate into things you are forced to do later. You don't have an online world to escape to or people to text for support; there is only the physical space of school, where you feel constantly watched and disconnected from everyone. This interaction is just another reminder that even when someone you're dating is supposed to care for you, you still end up feeling unsafe and alone.

You sit alone in the cafeteria, your high-volume tray of salads and sodas a stark contrast to the laughing groups around you. Their easy happiness is triggering, amplifying your own isolation and reminding you how different you feel in your body, even if you tell yourself your weight is fine. The food has no taste and brings no pleasure; it's just something to get through, a mechanical act in a life where enjoyment has long since faded.

dialogue.speaker: Liam
dialogue.text: Hey, picture day's next week. Time to practice not looking like a total zombie.

dialogue.speaker: Tavian
dialogue.text: Doesn't matter. My last one already looked like a mugshot.

dialogue.speaker: Liam
dialogue.text: Oh. Uh, right. Well, see you in history, man.

dialogue.speaker: Ms. Chen
dialogue.text: Tavian, I've noticed you've been absent a lot. Is everything alright?

dialogue.speaker: Tavian
dialogue.text: Just tired.

dialogue.speaker: Ms. Chen
dialogue.text: Okay. Well, if you need an extension on the project, please just let me know. I want to see you succeed.

dialogue.speaker: Tavian
dialogue.text: K.

dialogue.speaker: Jake
dialogue.text: Yo, put your seatbelt on before we go.

dialogue.speaker: Tavian
dialogue.text: It's fine. Don't worry about it.

dialogue.speaker: Jake
dialogue.text: Alright, your funeral. You doing anything later?

dialogue.speaker: Tavian
dialogue.text: Nah. Got stuff.

dialogue.speaker: Girlfriend
dialogue.text: Hey, I'm making a video. Smile!

dialogue.speaker: Tavian
dialogue.text: Not right now. I don't feel like it.

dialogue.speaker: Girlfriend
dialogue.text: Don't be so boring, Tavian. It's not that hard. Just do it.

dialogue.speaker: Tavian
dialogue.text: I can't. My head's just... not here right now.

daily_conversations.setting: At his locker before first period

dialogue.speaker: Maria
dialogue.text: Hey Tavian, did you understand the chem homework? I'm so lost.

dialogue.speaker: Tavian
dialogue.text: Didn't look at it.

dialogue.speaker: Maria
dialogue.text: Oh. You weren't in class yesterday, were you?

dialogue.speaker: Tavian
dialogue.text: Nope.
